trans-unit.source: An identifier is the representation within the language of items created by the user, as opposed to language keywords or commands.

seg-source.mrk: An identifier is the representation within the language of items created by the user, as opposed to language keywords or commands.

target.mrk: An identifier is the representation within the language of items created by the user, as opposed to language keywords or commands.

trans-unit.source: Some identifiers stand for dictionary objects, which are the objects you create- such as tables, views, indexes, columns, and constraints- that are stored in a database. They are called dictionary objects because stores information about them in the system tables, sometimes known as a data dictionary. SQL also defines ways to alias these objects within certain statements.

seg-source.mrk: Some identifiers stand for dictionary objects, which are the objects you create- such as tables, views, indexes, columns, and constraints- that are stored in a database.
They are called dictionary objects because <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> stores information about them in the system tables, sometimes known as a data dictionary.
SQL also defines ways to alias these objects within certain statements.

target.mrk: Some identifiers stand for dictionary objects, which are the objects you create- such as tables, views, indexes, columns, and constraints- that are stored in a database.
They are called dictionary objects because <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> stores information about them in the system tables, sometimes known as a data dictionary.
SQL also defines ways to alias these objects within certain statements.

trans-unit.source: Each kind of identifier must conform to a different set of rules. Identifiers representing dictionary objects must conform to SQL-92 identifier rules and are thus called SQL92Identifiers.

seg-source.mrk: Each kind of identifier must conform to a different set of rules.
Identifiers representing dictionary objects must conform to SQL-92 identifier rules and are thus called SQL92Identifiers.

target.mrk: Each kind of identifier must conform to a different set of rules.
Identifiers representing dictionary objects must conform to SQL-92 identifier rules and are thus called SQL92Identifiers.
